head.supplied: Derriweit Heights, ¶ Upper Macedon. ¶ My Dear Baron, ¶ ¶ I send you by this post a rough sketch of the plant you wished for. I think among the last new Western Australian ones you will find some new ...

div.p: RB MSS M1, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

Letter not found. The text used here is from a facsimile, presented as an eight-page leaflet, on the front page of which are the decorated initials 'E R' and a printed heading, 'Ellis Rowan, 1848-1922. | Baron Sir Ferdinand Von Mueller 1825-1896, Government Botanist of the State of Victoria 1852-1896.' The second page has a pencil sketch captioned: 'Ellis Rowan: A drawing by The Lady Casey from a photograph taken in about 1875.' The text of the letter is on the third and fourth pages. The fifth page is marked: 'Reproduction of a letter from Ellis Rowan to Baron Sir Ferdinand Von Mueller late 19th Century.' On the sixth page is printed a photgraph of a label, the writing on which is partly obscured by flowers, marked by M: 'Helipterum Manglesii F.v.Mueller.' A caption on the opposite page identifies it as 'Baron von Mueller's identification note of a wild flower specimen sent to the National Herbarium, Melbourne by Ellis Rowan.' The seventh page also shows a photograph of the plaque at the Melbourne Herbarium in memory of M: the caption to this notes that M's 'interest in Mrs Rowan's work was unflagging'. There are no details about when, why or by whom the leaflet was published. Derriweit Heights,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

div.p:
I send you by this post a rough sketch of the plant you wished for. I think among the last new Western Australian ones you will find some new varieties[.]
editorial addition. I have one very pretty Hibiscus I painted at Sharks Bay
Shark Bay, WA. which has a spotted leaf — when you have more time I will send them to you —
